name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖCreates a new Civilian Climate Corps to conserve our public lands, bolster community resilience, and address the changing climate, all while putting good-paying union jobs within reach for more Americans

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖAdvances environmental justice through a new Clean Energy and Sustainability Accelerator that will invest in projects around the country

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖDelivers substantial consumer rebates and tax credits to reduce costs for middle class families shifting to clean energy and electrification

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖMakes the single largest and most comprehensive investment in affordable housing IN HISTORY

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖMakes a transformative investment in Rural America through a new Rural Partnership Program that will empower rural regions, including Tribal Nations and territories, by providing flexible funding for locally led projects

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖIncreases the maximum Pell Grant by $550 for more the more than 5 million students enrolled in public and private, non-profit colleges

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖExpands access to affordable, high-quality education beyond high school. It will make education beyond high school ‚Äì including training for high-paying jobs available NOW ‚Äì more affordable

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖEmpowers communities to develop local economies & create jobs through a pilot of the RECOMPETE Act ‚Äì legislation I introduced to provide flexible, long-term grant assistance to help communities that have struggled to create jobs & create long-term economic growth & opportunity

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖExpands the Child Tax Credit, providing more than 35M households a tax credit up to $3,600/child - helping families cover the cost of food, housing, health care, & transportation. This tax cut has already enabled the largest 1-year reduction in child poverty in American HISTORY

tweet_text: ‚úÖExtends the expanded Earned Income Tax Credit for ~ 1‚É£7‚É£ million low-wage workers. The Build Back Better framework will extend the American Rescue Plan‚Äôs tripling of the credit for childless workers, benefiting 17 million low-wage workers, many of whom are essential workers

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: ‚úÖPermanently improves Medicaid coverage for home care services for seniors and people with disabilities, making the most transformative investment in access to home care in 40 years, when these services were first authorized for Medicaid.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
We need sanity to prevail in DC and for the two parties to work together to prevent default. 

The full faith and credit of our nation should never be in question.  ///

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: AND it‚Äôs despite the fact that Congressional Republicans and the last Administration racked up nearly $8 trillion in debt ‚Äì nearly 1/4 of our nation‚Äôs total debt ‚Äì in part to give the very wealthiest Americans a tax giveaway. I don‚Äôt say that in a partisan way - it‚Äôs just a fact.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
Senate Republicans have been threatening to filibuster ANY legislation to address the debt limit. 

That‚Äôs despite the fact that Mitch McConnell has previously said ‚ÄúAmerica must never default‚Äù and that failing to address it would be ‚Äúplaying Russian roulette with our economy.‚Äù

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
That‚Äôs why I supported legislation that passed the House on September 29 to suspend the debt limit.

Unfortunately, there are some shenanigans occurring in the U.S. Senate that has made the road forward a bit bumpy.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
((side note: this clip from The West Wing explains it in a far more entertaining way than I could ever))
https://t.co/xrEmqkqAW8

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
In essence, failing to address the debt ceiling is a bit like choosing not to pay the minimum balance on your credit card. 

You can make that choice ‚Äì but it DEFINITELY has bad consequences for your finances down the road.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
Recent analyses suggest that failure to act could cost America‚Äôs economy as much as 6‚É£ MILLION jobs. 

In addition, it would also likely delay payments for critical programs like Social Security, Medicare, and veterans‚Äô benefits.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
Again ‚Äì why does that matter? 

Well, nearly every economist across the political spectrum has acknowledged this would damage the economy and make it more expensive for folks to borrow money to buy a car or home, or to start or grow a small business.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: So why is this in the press right now? Well, it‚Äôs expected that the Treasury Department will run out of those options to address the debt ceiling by October 18. At that point, if Congress fails to take action, the government would default.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: Raising or suspending the debt limit does NOT authorize new spending but allows the government to pay for ‚û°Ô∏èpreviously made commitments‚¨ÖÔ∏è

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
Our nation is a bit unique in that it puts in law how much debt can be incurred by the U.S. Treasury. 

Why does that matter? Well, it limits the amount the federal government can pay on debt the government has ALREADY borrowed.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
There‚Äôs a fair amount of press attention about the debt ceiling (also known as the debt limit) - especially coming out of DC and the national news media.

What is it? Why does it matter to folks in our region? Is this actually a big deal (hint: yes)?

Let's dig in üßµ‚¨áÔ∏è

tweet_text:

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: Congress can, and should, pass both of these and help America #BuildBackBetter. I‚Äôll keep working toward that end.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: It‚Äôs about creating jobs by providing new help to small businesses and by taking action to combat the climate crisis.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: It‚Äôs about helping families that are grappling with the costs of child care or caring for an elder parent, that are struggling to pay for health care and prescription drugs, or that can‚Äôt afford to pay for college.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: The President‚Äôs Build Back Better bill (aka ‚Äúreconciliation‚Äù) is about helping middle class families.¬†It‚Äôs about recognizing that middle class families and folks struggling to make ends meet deserve a break.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: It‚Äôs about recognizing we can‚Äôt compete in a 21st Century economy with 19th & 20th Century infrastructure. The bipartisan infrastructure bill will create good-paying jobs, modernize our nation‚Äôs infrastructure, & reduce carbon pollution. Those are priorities worth moving forward

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: The bipartisan infrastructure bill is about putting people to work now ‚Äì and laying the foundation for economic growth over the long haul by investing in roads, bridges, transit, water systems, ports, and broadband.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: There‚Äôs been lots of press coverage of deliberations and process in Congress related to the President‚Äôs Build Back Better Agenda.¬†But let‚Äôs focus on what this is about‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs about jobs.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: This Thanksgiving season, I hope folks in Congress remember the words of President Kennedy who said, ‚ÄúAs we express our gratitude, we must never forget that the highest appreciation is not to utter words, but to live by them.‚Äù

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: Folks shouldn‚Äôt have to wait any longer. It‚Äôs time for Senate Republicans to come to the table and agree to an adequate relief package to support the American people. No more gridlock. No more pausing.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: >8 million Americans have fallen into poverty since May. W/ unemployment benefits expiring & stimulus payment seeming like a distant memory, things will only get worse. That‚Äôs why the House passed a relief bill to extend unemployment assistance & provide another round of payments

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: During this economic crisis, we‚Äôve seen people lose jobs, lose hours at work, and lose income‚Äîall factors exacerbating the threat of homelessness. That‚Äôs why the House passed a relief bill to provide rental assistance and protections from eviction and foreclosure.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: What‚Äôs more, people shouldn‚Äôt be threatened with the loss of their housing because of this pandemic. Nearly 11 million households in America spend more than 50 percent of their income on housing.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: To me, simply put, it is wrong that people are facing hunger this week. According to one nonprofit, nearly 50M Americans could be food insecure this year ‚Äì including 17M kids. That‚Äôs why the House passed a relief bill to provide nutrition assistance to reduce food insecurity.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
Now, more than ever, Democrats and Republicans need to come together and craft a relief package that meets the needs of Americans who are hurting. 

I have a sense of urgency about seeing a COVID relief bill pass.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text:
In the House, we‚Äôve already passed two different bills in recent months aimed at these goals. Unfortunately, the Senate has failed to act. Instead, Leader McConnell has said ‚Äúlet‚Äôs pause.‚Äù 

But the time for pausing has long needed to end.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: I‚Äôm working hard in these final weeks of the year to get a comprehensive COVID-19 relief bill passed that will crush this virus, provide assistance to folks who are unemployed or experiencing housing insecurity, and help small businesses on Main Street.

name: Rep. Derek Kilmer
tweet_text: It‚Äôs been 8 months since a comprehensive COVID-19 relief bill was last passed by Congress. It is shameful that more relief has not been provided to folks ‚Äì and this Thanksgiving weekend, I‚Äôm thinking about the people who need Congress to act.
